5]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eComing off a year like no other,\u003c/strong\u003e brands are under unprecedented pressure. Much ink has been spilled on consumer loyalty and expectations, brand response to social issues, and digital acceleration. Loyalty to consumer products is up for grabs, and the dialogue between brands and consumers \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/survey-us-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis\"\u003eremains important\u003c/a\u003e. But more than ever, the most successful consumer packaged goods (CPG) brands will be those that can navigate a wider range of stakeholders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eStakeholder expectations for brands are increasingly conflated with expectations for the companies that build and manage them. Brands can no longer be kept at arm\u0026rsquo;s length from the corporate parent\u0026mdash;particularly for corporations named for their largest brands. This increases the range of topics and perspectives to monitor and action for brand managers and brand owners.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eTo help brands and brand owners thrive under these pressures, Consumer Brands Association, in collaboration with McKinsey \u0026amp; Company which provided data and analysis for this report, examine expectations from five key stakeholder groups: consumers, retailers, employees, investors, and government. These insights combine primary research\u0026mdash;including a survey of nearly 5,000 consumers in the United States and interviews with more than 20 retailers, chief human resource officers at leading consumer brands, and experts\u0026mdash;with an analysis of publicly available investor perspectives, metrics, and policy documents.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe research focused on exploring tangible expectations and their relative importance and actionability across stakeholders, which varied in unexpected ways (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eFive familiar themes emerged:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBrand authenticity:\u003c/strong\u003e Live what you stand for\u0026mdash;and choose consciously where and how you speak up.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSustainability:\u003c/strong\u003e Investors leading the charge\u0026mdash;move the needle on something tangible, measurable, and understandable.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDiversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI):\u003c/strong\u003e Transparency and inclusivity are no regrets.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIntegrated experiences:\u003c/strong\u003e Collaborate to reach consumers\u0026mdash;nail the basics, be a data maker, and curate across physical and digital touchpoints.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFuture of work:\u003c/strong\u003e Talent agility and automation will not be optional in a shifting labor market.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003e1. Brand authenticity: Live what you stand for\u0026mdash;and choose consciously where and how you speak up\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAuthenticity\u0026mdash;when defined as brand transparency or consistency\u0026mdash;is a table-stakes expectation of all stakeholders. When brands clearly articulate what they stand for, and act accordingly, they deepen their perceived authenticity in the eyes of employees, consumers, and retailers (Exhibit 2). These groups also distinguish authenticity from vocal brand activism: speaking out on social issues is more effective when causes align with brand purpose. While the importance of authenticity is not new, today\u0026rsquo;s greater scrutiny of brand action and inaction makes it imperative that brands act consistently with their purpose.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003eTransparency and consistency: Table stakes across stakeholders\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eBrand transparency, honesty, and consistency of products and positioning were regarded as particularly important in all stakeholder groups. Across interviews, stakeholders ranked authenticity as the most essential of expectations, rating it more than four out of five in importance. Brands that fall short of this bar risk losing share, shelf space, and talent, while facing the ire of investors and regulators.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eBrand purpose and story: Resonating with consumers and employees\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eA meaningful, resonant brand story\u0026mdash;inspirational founders, brand origins, product ingredients, or social mission\u0026mdash;is a powerful way to amplify perceived authenticity, connect to consumers, and drive loyalty. \u0026ldquo;A brand for someone like me\u0026rdquo; is the top loyalty driver (Exhibit 3). Resonance also attaches to \u0026ldquo;a brand I\u0026rsquo;m proud to buy\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;that shares my values.\u0026rdquo; Misalignment could cost brands market share: 37 percent of millennials, while not the majority, indicated that they would stop buying a brand that was not aligned to their values.[[footnote 1]] This echoes a previous survey which found that purpose was a primary reason for switching brands.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 3]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eRetailers prioritize brands with purpose and values that are consistent with their own, and whose stories resonate with their customers. For example, retailers noted brands aligned with their values on sourcing and transparency, such as Vital Farms, whose packaging for eggs includes the farm name; online, you can find its location and other product-sourcing information.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFor employees, purpose and authenticity are also important considerations when choosing an employer\u0026mdash;82 percent believe it is important for a brand to have a purpose, while two-thirds of millennials take an employer\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts/purpose-before-profits-employees-say-yes-please\"\u003esocial and environmental commitments\u003c/a\u003e into account when deciding \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts/purpose-before-profits-employees-say-yes-please\"\u003ewhere to work\u003c/a\u003e. Having a clear purpose helps brands attract and retain employees, and achieve the highest levels of engagement from them. One CPG leader mentioned the \u0026ldquo;cocktail-party test\u0026rdquo;: are employees excited to say they work for Brand X, or are they embarrassed by a tarnished corporate reputation?\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[pullquote 1]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003eBrand activism: Focus on the right issues\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe majority of consumers\u0026mdash;61 percent across all generations\u0026mdash;want brands to take action on societal issues. This expectation increases to 76 percent for millennials and Gen-Z consumers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies need to be thoughtful about where and how to engage in vocal activism, as both brand and employer. Even while 61 percent of consumers want brands to take action\u0026mdash;or do the right thing\u0026mdash;only 30 percent of consumers want to hear brands speak out about those actions.[[footnote 3]] It is a delicate balance, as vocal brand activism can also come into conflict with organizational inclusivity, particularly for brand owners with a diverse and geographically dispersed workforce.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat this means for brands\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBrands and brand owners should be conscious about which issues align with their values, and share positions transparently with consumers and employees.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOnce they have articulated what they stand for, they should act in line with those values, across product design, messaging, supply chain, employee policies, and more.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eA brand\u0026rsquo;s values should guide it on when to enter the arena. Loyalty will wane for brands that fail to act in line with what they stand for.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003e2. Sustainability: Investors leading the charge\u0026mdash;move the needle on something tangible, measurable, and understandable\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eWe have reached an inflection point on sustainability, and investors are leading the way.[[footnote 4]] As influential stakeholders, investors are pushing enterprises for change and accountability\u0026mdash;and employees are backing them up. Consumers as a whole are not currently selecting brands, or paying premiums, for sustainability, but younger generations demonstrate strong preferences for greener brands.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eInvestors and employees are holding brands accountable\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThere has been a fundamental shift in how sustainability influences investment decisions. We are seeing growing capital inflows into what was once a niche \u0026ldquo;sustainability thesis.\u0026rdquo; For example, flows to US sustainability-focused funds increased fivefold between the first quarter of 2019 and 2021.[[footnote 5]] Surveys of institutional investors have shown a growing number are incorporating ESG (environmental, social, and governance) considerations into investment decisions.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eInvestment professionals believe contributions to environmental programs substantially \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-esg-premium-new-perspectives-on-value-and-performance\"\u003eimpact shareholder value\u003c/a\u003e in the long term, by enhancing corporate reputation or brand equity. Employees also see sustainability as an extension of brand authenticity: where it fits into the brand story, employees are energized by sustainability commitments\u0026mdash;and will hold brands accountable for them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, the investment community would like reporting on ESG to be more reliable, consistent, and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/why-esg-is-here-to-stay\"\u003etied to value\u003c/a\u003e. The SEC has been considering disclosures related to climate risk.[[footnote 7]] Much of this may be changing soon, with the announcement of the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB), charged with developing global reporting standards\u0026mdash;a development coming out of the COP26 UN Climate Change Conference.[[footnote 8]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eYounger consumers have stronger, greener preferences\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eConsumers are not currently the primary influencers for greater brand sustainability: about 40 percent of surveyed consumers said that environmental responsibility or sustainability was important to them, and only around a third indicated a willingness to pay more than a ten-percent premium for sustainable practices, such as recyclable packaging; fair-trade practices; carbon-footprint reduction; or organic farming.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, this will evolve as younger generations, who place a greater premium on sustainability, increase their buying power (Exhibits 4, 5). Sixty-one percent of Gen-Z respondents are aware of brand sustainability commitments, compared with only 21 percent of Boomers. Fourteen percent of Gen Z respondents and 25 percent of millennials reported spending more on sustainability than the previous year. These younger generations are also increasing in influence. Millennials have already surpassed Boomers as a proportion of the population, and in ten years, Gen Z\u0026rsquo;s income is expected to exceed that of millennials.[[footnote 9]] Further, with 61 percent of younger Americans likely to organically post about brands they like, compelling sustainability commitments can shape the brand narrative spread on social media by consumers.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 4]]\n\n[[exhibit 5]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eFor retailers, the pressure to honor external commitments, manage their own sourcing, and offer options for younger shoppers will increasingly affect CPGs. All retail stakeholders interviewed indicated the increasing importance of environmental and sustainability goals. They are also actively rolling out initiatives to achieve these commitments, and communicating these to their shoppers. Some of these commitments\u0026mdash;for example, net waste reduction, packaging optimization, or distribution route optimization\u0026mdash;are driven by operational improvements. Retailers noted that these environmental goals have not all translated into expectations of their CPG partners and expect further trickledown effect on brands in the future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat this means for brands\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAction here is imperative.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt is necessary to define metrics that are meaningful and measurable.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWith the right metrics, brands can translate their commitments into a realistic roadmap with tangible initiatives.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAccountability to their stakeholders requires them to clearly report on these, and the value driven by their actions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003e3. Diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI): Transparency and inclusivity are no regrets\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eDEI is of increasing importance to multiple stakeholders; but, as with sustainability, expectations are not consistent across stakeholders. Execution of retailer DEI aspirations, for example, is mostly left to the discretion of individual buyers, leaving brands without a clear blueprint. However, this will change over time as retailers formalize policies and younger generations increase buying power.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eRetailers are spreading the word\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eInternally, retailers are prioritizing DEI efforts\u0026mdash;more than four out of five indicated that DEI has increased in importance over the last two to five years. However, retailer expectations around DEI are not currently being translated into well-defined, enterprise-wide expectations of CPG brands, leaving individual buyers to make the decisions. This is complicated by the fact that DEI is difficult to track or measure uniformly, and is often subjective. For example, some buyers may value gender diversity in the sales team they are in contact with, while others may be more interested in the commitments a company has made to their local community.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, this buyer-driven approach may soon change. Retailers are also becoming more transparent about DEI, and making more information available to their shoppers\u0026mdash;for example, Ahold Delhaize USA\u0026rsquo;s Giant Food identifies which products on its shelves are from minority-owned businesses.[[footnote 11]] Similarly, food-delivery leaders like DoorDash note which restaurants are women- or minority-owned.[[footnote 12]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 6]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003eConsumer spending habits lag behind interest\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eWhile the importance of DEI is rising for consumers, most do not yet factor it into their decision making. Only about 30 percent of consumers consider brand commitment to DEI when deciding what to buy. However, more consumer groups are beginning to give this serious consideration, particularly when evaluating if a brand is \u0026ldquo;for them.\u0026rdquo; Black consumers rated the importance of DEI between 15 and 20 percentage points higher than white or Asian consumers. Additionally, 17 percent of Black and 14 percent of Hispanic and Latino consumers indicated that they would be willing to spend in excess of 25 percent more for brands supporting DEI; among Gen-Z and millennial respondents, almost half would pay 10 percent more (Exhibit 7).[[footnote 13]] As with sustainability, this will increase in importance as demographics shift, and younger consumers are likely to amplify resonant brand commitments to DEI on social media today.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 7]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003eEmployee inclusion is critical\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFor brand owners, commitment to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-organization-blog/personal-experience-of-inclusion-critical-to-win-the-war-for-talent\"\u003eDEI remains critical\u003c/a\u003e to attracting and retaining top talent, as well as delivering top performance. Employees are looking for a sense of belonging and to be valued, and brand owners cannot offer these things, or sustain a diverse workforce, without an inclusive culture and environment. And, for many employees, it is not about hearing what the initiatives are, but about seeing them in action.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat this means for brands\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe business case for diversity is strong. The likelihood of \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/diversity-wins-how-inclusion-matters\"\u003efinancial outperformance is consistently higher\u003c/a\u003e for companies with gender and ethnic diversity in their executive teams\u0026mdash;companies with the most gender-diverse leadership were 48 percent more likely to outperform the least gender-diverse companies\u0026mdash;and it is the right thing to do. More stakeholders will place greater emphasis on DEI over time, and produce clearer guidelines; brands will benefit from getting ahead of this trend.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhile brands and brand owners may not be able to effect change across the board all at once, pursuing inclusivity in your organization is a no-regrets proposition.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe complexities here are not going away. To manage the sometimes competing expectations of various stakeholders, brand owners will need dedicated focus and attention at the C-suite level to get the details right.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003e4. Integrated experiences: Collaborate to reach consumers\u0026mdash;nail the basics, be a data maker, and curate across physical and digital touchpoints\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eWith the shift to omnichannel shopping, consumers expect seamless experiences across channels. Few consumers report visiting a brand site directly, so brands need additional ways to build strong direct relationships with consumers and reach them across platforms, including through collaboration with retailers and via media channels.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eThe rising bar for consumer experiences\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eConsumers expect more from brands they support. For 80 percent of consumers, seamless experiences across channels, and product availability wherever they shop, are highly important.[[footnote 14]] Expectations for the frictionless digital experiences created by e-commerce leaders expand across brand sites, third-party e-commerce, and offline retail. Brands can deliver more integrated experiences by connecting offline retail and digital. This has been seen through the increase of click-and-collect shopping, which gives consumers \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/making-online-grocery-a-winning-proposition\"\u003ebetter insight\u003c/a\u003e into inventory information and their orders. CPG brands can also look to other close-in sectors that are further along in their digital maturity for inspiration.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eWhere consumers are\u0026mdash;and aren\u0026rsquo;t\u0026mdash;looking\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eConsumers look to several sources for direct access to brands. Few consumers regularly visit a CPG website\u0026mdash;only about 7 percent visited in the past three months. Those that do however, are looking to purchase products or find product information.[[footnote 15]] Brands can build direct relationships and collect privacy-safe customer data by offering direct-to-consumer (DTC) sales, product information, or engaging experiences; with a stronger data foundation, brands can raise the bar on communications.[[footnote 16]] To best capitalize on the digital consumer, brands will need to look beyond their own site to channels where they have less control over their brand voice.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFor Gen Z, social media\u0026mdash;primarily TikTok and YouTube\u0026mdash;has eclipsed other influencing forces: 39 percent indicated their purchase decisions are swayed by social media; 24 percent by point of sale; and only 14 percent by friends and family.[[footnote 17]] To reach consumers earlier in their decision journey, brand managers should identify the platforms and channels where their brands command the greatest attention.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003ePhysical retail still matters, even with digital on the rise\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn-store point of purchase still matters, both to consumers and to retailers looking to deliver differentiated experiences. While click-and-collect is on the rise in some channels (grocery, mass), physical stores remain the primary point of purchase\u0026mdash;about 75 percent of purchases still take place here, and 5 percent through click-and-collect, according to consumers. Boomers\u0026rsquo; purchase decisions are more influenced at physical point of purchase than other generations\u0026rsquo;, but millennials and Gen Z still meaningfully purchase in-store as well.[[footnote 18]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThis presents an opportunity for brands through differentiated, omnichannel experiences co-created with retail partners. Retailers noted that digital acceleration and omnichannel experiences will only increase in importance, and that they want to offer such experiences to compete better.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eConsumers are looking to brands to understand them throughout their journey to engage with them\u0026mdash;whether that be in-store or on-line\u0026mdash;for a tailored and seamless experience. Retailers are also looking for this, and retail media networks could be part of the potential solution. These networks enable brands to deploy shopper marketing dollars to target consumers on a \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/high-growth-low-profit-the-e-commerce-dilemma-for-cpg-companies\"\u003eretailer\u0026rsquo;s digital platforms\u003c/a\u003e. Such relationships will deepen in importance as new privacy regulations take effect, and third-party cookie tracking continues to wane.[[footnote 19]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[pullquote 2]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat this means for brands\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBrands need deeper direct relationships with consumers to deliver the seamless experiences they have come to expect across channels. With the right value propositions for consumers a brand\u0026rsquo;s site can be a powerful tool for reaching consumers and gaining insights.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBrands need to identify the digital and physical touchpoints that influence consumers and deploy resources accordingly\u0026mdash;even when brands do not own the touchpoint in question.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRetailers would like to collaborate across channels.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003e5. Future of work: Talent agility and automation will not be optional in a shifting labor market\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAs expectations on brands increase across all stakeholders, so will the pressure on the workforces of the brand owners who make, sell, and deliver them. With the great talent reshuffle, companies are facing shortages, with more than 130,000 job openings in the CPG industry right now.[[footnote 20]] At the same time, there are longer-term trends playing out that will have major impact on brand owners: new capabilities are needed to win; employees have evolving priorities for how they pick employers, including flexibility, investment in employees, and a sense of purpose; and digital disruptions and automation are on the horizon.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eNew capabilities are needed to meet expectations\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 2]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eBrand owners face increasing demands that will only become more difficult to meet, especially with the labor shortage. Consumers expect \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/personalizing-the-customer-experience-driving-differentiation-in-retail\"\u003egreater personalization\u003c/a\u003e, efficiency, and transparency, while retailers place a premium on brands that can minimize supply-chain friction, and suppliers with whom it is easy to do business. To deliver on these expectations at scale, the CPG sector will need to invest in critical enablers, particularly talent and automation\u0026mdash;areas where CPGs risk falling behind other industries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eEmployee needs and expectations are evolving\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe existing workforce does not have the right skill set to meet future role demands, so brands need to make large, strategic bets on upskilling their employees, both to retain their workforce and to get ahead of future skills shortages. Unilever, for example, is committing to reskill or upskill all employees by 2025 to ensure they have a future-fit skill set.[[footnote 21]] Three-quarters of employees felt it was important for companies to invest in skill development and training to help employees adapt to technological changes impacting their job.[[footnote 22]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn order to attract and retain talent, brand owners will also need to offer \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/what-employees-are-saying-about-the-future-of-remote-work\"\u003egreater flexibility\u003c/a\u003e. Flexible work is more readily achievable for back-office employees; providing similar flexibility to frontline employees remains a challenge. It is also important to address employees\u0026rsquo; desire to feel valued and have a sense of purpose\u0026mdash;which, as we have seen, can be achieved through the brand\u0026rsquo;s actions on inclusion, sustainability, brand purpose, and authenticity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[pullquote 3]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003eAutomation and digital: CPG well-positioned, with room to grow\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAs CPG companies strive to meet heightened demand expectations from retailers and consumers, automation can be part of the solution to meet labor shortages. Compared to other sectors, consumer goods, including CPG, apparel, and household products manufacturing, has the highest potential for automation, and thus for disruption\u0026mdash;64 percent of current activities can be automated.[[footnote 23]] The increase in automation is expected to shift the type of work being done.[[footnote 24]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThis is not an easy transition, but there have been some examples of success. The World Economic Forum recognizes 12 global CPG manufacturing lighthouses, for achieving transformative innovation at scale. These locations have \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-digital-future-of-manufacturing-consumer-packaged-goods\"\u003eshown improvements\u003c/a\u003e across dimensions key to both consumers and retailers, including greater speed-to-market, lead-time reduction, and enhanced productivity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat this means for brands\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTo meet increasing stakeholder demands on other dimensions, brand owners need to address the labor shortage and harness technology.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAgility, including upskilling and location flexibility, will be needed to win the war for talent.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIncreased investment in automation and emerging technologies can help the CPG sector build from a good position, to leading across industries.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eConclusion\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eConsumer brands and brand owners are under unprecedented pressure. They are navigating more complex stakeholder networks, while managing increasing\u0026mdash;and occasionally conflicting\u0026mdash;expectations across a wide range of topics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eBrands best positioned to gain share in this environment will be transparent about what they stand for; make and honor measurable commitments to ESG and DEI; build their direct and indirect relationships with consumers across digital and physical touchpoints; and harness talent and technology. These brands will collect granular data on stakeholders, identify shifts in expectations, prioritize in line with their values, and act boldly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eStakeholders are issuing a call to action for brands to win their loyalty on the dimensions that matter\u0026mdash;with outsize returns for those that do.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-12-09T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMcKinsey \u0026amp;
